My mother had knee pain for which doctor advised its osteo artheritis and would require surgery. But he gave 2 tablets to relieve her from the inflammation and pain. My mother took the medicine in the night and next day she had vomiting and heaviness in the head. The vomiting lasted for almost 8 hrs with mild headache and dizziness. When I called the doctor to inform about the situation he said its the side effect of the tablet. Instead of suggesting an alternate medicine  he suggested me to take her to some other nearby hospital. Very bad people management.
reply_text: Adverse drug effects(allergies or reactions) are rare, but do happen. In such rare circumstances, stopping the medicine usually improves the situation. In cases of unexplained discomfort/symptoms, patients are advised to come back to us for a follow up. In case that is not possible, they are advised to go to a nearby hospital emergency department for a check up as other illnesses have to be ruled out. Medicines wont be prescribed based on telephone conversations, without checking the patients. This protocol is followed for safety of the patient, and the inconvenience caused is unavoidable.

review:
I reached on time. Found the doc to be very dull. He was not very interested in listening to my problems. He dint even ask me what caused the problem. He just told that "general procedure is we ask for treatment and then we go for MRI". That I guess everyone knows.
He dint even asked about my day to day physical activities which i do. Which might cause pain in knee. I had to ask myself that Is climbing stairs OK or is riding bike OK. He dint even tell me the kind of exercises I need to do and just told that I need to go for physiotherapy without telling any exercises or anything. When I tried to describe my problem, he asked me if I know the name of that ligament in a very sarcastic way. Overall bad experience and will not recommend.
reply_text: Patient had a 15 year old knee ligament injury which has not healed well. Patient was unwilling for Xrays as he felt Xrays are done only for diagnosis of fractures which is a misconception. In chronic ligament injuries, Xrays are required for looking at the alignment and shape of the bones, and MRI is required for assessing the soft tissue structures(ligaments and menisci). In the face of unwillingness to evaluate the joint in detail, our hands are tied in offering any permanent solution. Unfortunately, there is no single shot treatment or quickfix for such issues.

He suggested tablets also giving side effects and did not improve any things at least 1% also.
Yesterday, he gave different tablet and asked to stop previous tablet.
But, new tablets are giving another issues like vomiting ,unconscious mind...etc. 
Now, I have decided to go another hospital to verify the same...

He will play the tricks to get the X-Rays even though not required and getting 2-3 views even though one view is enough...etc.
He will try to convince you some thing  irrelevant.....etc.
reply_text:
Pain in another joint after 6-7 months, as in this case, would obviously require different Xrays. To assume that we can treat a shoulder problem with Xrays of the lower back done 6 months ago is ridiculous. Most orthopaedic problems will need Xrays, which is a basic investigation. It is standard practice all over the world to take 2 or even 3 views of a particular joint. Xray examination is incomplete with inadequate views. We follow established protocols in treating every patient. There is no magic involved, neither is there any trickery. Certain problems have easy solutions, certain chronic degenerative conditions may only partially subside.

Every guest in our center is explained the requirement of a particular xray if the nature and duration of the problem warrants it. There is no compulsion to do the Xrays or any investigations at our center. We have a fixed charge for Xrays and they are not included in consultation fees.

Hope, this clarifies the picture for all future guests to our clinic.

- Team Osteon.

reply_text:
We follow standard practices and protocols for requesting Xrays and other investigations. Long standing conditions of bone and joint(months to years) will mostly require xrays of the involved area and blood tests relevant to the condition for effective management.

In this particular case, patient already had a single xray of the lower back which was prescribed by a general practitioner. As a single xray is inadequate to assess the spine, the other Xray view was requested and done. Incomplete xray studies are useless for deciding on management of the condition. A condition was detected on the xray and explained to patient. Blood tests relevant to assess severity were asked for.
